Dialogue:
Person1: 657-2036
Person2: Hello -- who is this?
Person1: This is Dr. Smith's answering service.
Person2: Is the doctor anywhere?
Person1: Well -- you see -- the doctor is at his son's wedding, but I'm sure it's over by now. He should be checking in any moment --
Person2: Listen to me. I am Dr. Smith's brother -- Reverend Smith -- and I am supposed to perform the ceremony. I just got in -- from -- Portland -- and I've forgotten what church -- you see?

Person1: Allison? Why can't remember what happened to my wife? Is it something I'm on that's... that's making me forget?
Person2: Easy there Trevor. You need to relax.
Person1: No I need to remember. Look whatever it is take me off it. I can handle pain. I can't handle not knowing...
Person2: You need to get better first Trevor. Way better.  It's okay to miss somebody. It's okay to still love someone after they're gone. But you've got to quit blaming yourself okay...? Okay?

Person1: Fox, Bud D. is this deja vu or has it really been a year. You're not hitting me up for NYU are you?
Person2: Well we're thinking of putting up a statue of you in the subway. I hear you're moving up in the world. An associate already. Not bad. How's Margie?
Person1: Can't complain. Got a house in Oyster Bay. Market treating you good? Still seeing that sexy French gal?
Person2: Nah, she asked the wrong question.
Person1: What was that?
Person2: "What are you thinking?"...that was it. The hours are hell, but the money's starting to tumble in. I know this guy who's got an iron- clad way to make money, I can't lose and I can't get hurt.
Person1: So, does "this guy" have a tip for an honest lawyer?
Person2: Yeah, check out Teldar Paper, it's still not over.
Person1: Okay.
Person2: What about you, I hear you guys are handling the Fairchild Foods merger and it may not be going through. Any surprises I haven't read about in the Wall Street Journal?
Person1: Come on Buddy, you wouldn't want to got me disbarred now would you?
Person2: Who's listening? It's just one college buddy talking to another.
Person1: Yeah, right...
Person2: Relax, Roger, everybody's doing it but you don't know, you don't know.
Person1: ...and if I did, what's in it for moi?

Person1: I have this thing where I have to know a person is being honest with me before, you know, I can feel completely free to be myself.
Person2: We're strangers in the night. The last thing we want is honesty.
Person1: What do we want?
Person2: Mystery. Deception.
Person1: Deception isn't something I personally consider sexy.
Person2: What's sexy?
Person1: Knowing who a person is. Down deep.
Person2: Even if the truth about a person is sad or depressing or shocking?
Person1: You won't even tell me your name. What's shocking about a name?

Person1: ...Come in here...I work here, I don't come in here to be mistreated...
Person2: Go to lunch, will you...
Person1: I want to work today, that's why I came...
Person2: The leads come in, I'll let...
Person1: ...that's why I came in.  I thought I...
Person2: Just go to lunch.
Person1: I don't want to go to lunch.
Person2: Go to lunch, George.
Person1: Where does he get off to talk that way to a working man?  It's not...
Person2: Will you take it outside, we have people trying to do business here...
Person1: That's what, that's what, that's what I was trying to do.  That's why I came in...I meet gestapo tac...
Person2: Excuse me...

Person1: Looks like we got a couple of live ones. How long these boys in for?
Person2: Judge gave 'em the long ride.
Person1: Life, huh? They step outta line again, we'll shorten up that sentence real fast.

Person1: Now, wait a minute, Dad...
Person2: Sure. What's worth doing is worth doing for money. It's a bad bargain where nobody gains. And if this deal goes through, we all gain.

Person1: I'm going to kill myself.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Because you think I'm all like... "Hey man, check me out".
Person2: No, I don't think you're like, "I'm charming and mysterious in a way that even I don't understand and something about me is crying out for protection from a big man like you".  Very hard to compete with.  Especially to us married women who have lost our mystery.
Person1: But you haven't lost your mystery! You're very mysterious!
Person2: No.  I'm weird.  Weird and mysterious are two different things.
Person1: But I'm weird.
Person2: No.  You're quirky.  Quirky and weird are two different things.
Person1: Peggy, there's distinct possibility that I might be profoundly and irreversibly screwed up.  Despite that, I love you and I can promise that I will no longer flirt with Cory, and I beg your forgiveness.

Person1: Look. I'm a little worried about this -- this whole thing with my mother, he admitted to the Professor. I mean, I don't know if I can do it -- I mean, hitting on my own mother, that's pretty heavy.
Person2: Nobody said anything about hitting her! You're just going to take a few liberties with her.
Person1: That's exactly what I said! I mean, a guy and his mother -- that's illegal, isn't it?
Person2: Look, Marty, she's not your mother yet. And if you don't go through with this, she may never be. I know it's hard, but there are some things we must do in life that are unpleasant. Some choices must be made that are difficult. Nonetheless, we must make them. Besides, this may be more than a simple question of your own existence, he added. The fate of the entire space-time continuum may rest on your shoulders . Marty tried to smile at him.
Person1: That's just what I needed to hear.
Person2: It'll be fine, Marty.  You'll be fine. Good luck. He stuck his hand out and Marty shook it. But there was still a question that was nagging at him...
Person1: Professor, if something does go wrong tonight... if I don't get my parents back together... when do you think I'd cease to exist?

Person1: DO YOU WANNA DIE?!
Person2: No.
Person1: Yes you do...
Person2: Look, I'm talking about a business deal here.  I buy the ticket for two hundred, take it to a store where the guy behind the counter...  ...doesn't have a death wish  ...I just made myself a quick thirty eight dollars.

Person1: _Answer_ me.
Person2: We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.  Then he figured out the birth records in Church Hill...

Person1: Boeman don't. You know I'm right.
Person2: Are you crazy?! Pull the lever!

Person1: I don't work with spooks.  Not after that op in Cambodia.
Person2: I'm authorized to get you out of here.  I thought that's what you wanted.
Person1: What's the job?
Person2: Classic special forces op... hit fast... in and out.  Two men.  Two days.
Person1: Why me?
Person2: We like you.  At least the computer at Langley likes you.  Pulled your file because of various factors.  Service record. Area familiarity.
Person1: Where?
Person2: Not yet.
Person1: I'm not jumping blind.

Person1: I don't like thinking about the accident.  I don't even remember it happening.  Besides, it just makes people feel sorry for me, and...
Person2: You hate that.

Person1: She wouldn't get out of the car.  I brought her all the way here, she said she was going to come here, and she wouldn't get out of the car.  But I thought that is was important, that she come to see you, because I know that if you go somewhere and you don't deal with your family stuff, then you're just gonna, she's gonna, um...
Person2: Are you going to England with her Lloyd?
Person1: That's one of the things I wanted to talk to you about sir.
Person2: Are you?
Person1: Am I going?  Am I going to England?  I've thought about this quite a bit, and I've realised what I probably should do is just carve out a goal for my future and find out what I wanna do with my life, do all the stuff that I've been avoiding in a big way. I mean, Diane and I can wait for each other, right?  What's she gonna... she's gonna run off with some English guy?  There's no way.
Person2: Well Lloyd, I admire you for not hitching a ride.  You know, my daughter's a lot different to you.
Person1: I know.
Person2: She's very successful.
Person1: I know
Person2: Very talented.
Person1: I know.  But then I reconsidered.  'Cause I figured out what I really wanna do with my life, what I want to do for a living is I wanna be with your daughter.  I'm good at it.
Person2: You're not a permanent part of her life.  You're a distraction.
Person1: I'm the distraction that's going to England with her sir.  Are you alright sir?  Are you okay?
Person2: I'm incarcerated, Lloyd!  I don't deserve to lose my daughter over this.  I don't deserve to have you as my go-between.  And I can't for the life of me figure out how she could choose to champion in mediocrity the way she flirts around you.

Person1: You heartless jerk.
Person2: Don't you get it?  They had their 2,000 years.  Now it's our turn.
Person1: So all that bullshit about God and faith.
Person2: It was perfect.  The harder I pushed, the more you pulled away.
Person1: You lied to me my whole life. Everything you said, everything you did.
Person2: Everything I did, I did for you.  I love you, Peter.  Think of it.  I'm giving you a gift, absolute power and knowledge.
Person1: You raised me, like a son.
Person2: You are my son.  Don't you see the opportunity that lies before you?
Person1: You killed my parents.
Person2: I had to.  There was no other way. Their deaths were part of the greatest legacy I could have given you.

Person1: You see what I mean?  That reaction would give us away in a second.  Try to relax.
Person2: It's just that... it's been sixteen years since anyone but Harry did that, I--
Person1: Relax.  There, that's better. Let yourself slip into the role.

Person1: All right, sugar, what's on your mind?
Person2: Don't look at me like that. Auggie. It gives me the creeps.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Like what you're doing. I'm not going to eat you up.  I need your help, and if you keep staring at me like that. I might start screaming.
Person1: Help, huh? And I don't suppose this help has anything to do with money, does it?
Person2: Don't rush me, okay? You're jumping to conclusions before I've even said anything.  And besides, it's not for me.  It's for our daughter.
Person1: Our daughter? Is that what you said? Our daughter? I mean, you might have a daughter, but I sure as hell don't. And even if I did -- which I don't -- she wouldn't be our daughter.
Person2: Her name is Felicity, and she just turned eighteen.  She ran away from Pittsburgh last year, and now she's living in some shit-hole here in Brooklyn with a guy named Chico. Strung out on crack, four months pregnant.  I can't bear to think about that baby. Our grandchild, Auggie. Just think of it. Our grandchild.
Person1: Stop it, already. Just stop all this crap right now.  Was that your idea to call her Felicity?
Person2: It means "happiness."
Person1: I know what it means. That still don't make it a good name.
Person2: I don't know who else to turn to, Auggie.
Person1: You've suckered me before, darling, remember? Why should I believe you now?
Person2: Why would I lie to you, Auggie? You think it was easy to come here and walk into this place? Why would I do it if I didn't have to?
Person1: That's what you told me when I shoplifted that necklace for you. You remember, baby, don't you? The judge gave me a choice, either go to the can or enlist. So, instead of going to college, I wind up in the navy for four years, I watch men lose their arms and legs, I nearly get my head blown off, and you, sweet Ruby McNutt, you run off and marry that asshole, Bill.
Person2: You didn't write to me for more than a year. What was I supposed to think?
Person1: Yeah, well, I lost my pen. By the time I got a new one, I was clean out of paper.
Person2: It was over with Bill before you ever came home. Maybe you don't remember it now, but you were pretty hot to see me back then.
Person1: You weren't so lukewarm yourself. At least at first.
Person2: It fizzled, baby. That's the way it goes. But we had our times, didn't we? It wasn't all bad.
Person1: A couple of moments, I'll grant you that. A second or two snatched from the jaws of eternity.
Person2: And that's how Felicity came into the picture. During one of those two seconds.
Person1: You're conning me, sweetheart. I ain't responsible for no baby.
Person2: Then why do you think I married Frank? I was already pregnant, and I didn't have much time. Say what you like, but at least he gave my kid a name.
Person1: Good old Frank. And how is fat Mr. Grease Monkey these days?
Person2: Who the hell knows?  He dropped out of sight fifteen years ago.
Person1: Fifteen years ago?  It won't wash, pumpkin. No mother waits fifteen years to tell a man he's a father. I wasn't born yesterday, you know.
Person2: I thought I could handle it. I didn't want to bug you. I thought I could handle it on my own, but I couldn't. She's in real bad, Auggie.
Person1: Nice try, old girl. I'd like to help you out. You know, for old time's sake. But all my spare cash is tied up in a business venture, and I haven't collected my profits yet. Too bad. You caught me at the wrong time.
Person2: You're a cold-hearted bastard, aren't you? How'd you ever get so mean, Auggie?
Person1: I know you think I'm lying to you, but I'm not. Every word I told you is the God's honest truth.

Person1: Mozart, are you aware I have declared the French play of Figaro unsuitable for our theatre?
Person2: Yes, Sire.
Person1: Yet we hear you are making an opera from it. Is this true?
Person2: Who told you this, Majesty?
Person1: It is not your place to ask questions. Is it true?
Person2: Well, yes, I admit it is.
Person1: Would you tell me why?
Person2: Well, Majesty, it is only a comedy.

Person1: I had a chat with Liam, and he mentioned the weekend trip you two are planning.
Person2: Oh, that? Thought I mentioned it in passing.
Person1: You never told me that. I had other plans for us this weekend.
Person2: You always assume I'm available. Maybe if you checked in more, we wouldn't have this confusion.
Person1: Communication goes both ways, Henry.
Person2: And maybe you shouldn't rely on third parties to know my plans.

Person1: No, don't be silly. What-what do we need other people for?  You know, we should-we should just turn out the lights, you know, and play hide and seek or something.
Person2: Well, okay. Well, listen, I'm gonna get a cigarette, okay?
Person1: Yeah, grass, right? The illusion that it will make a white woman more like Billie Holiday.
Person2: Well, have you ever made love high?
Person1: Me, no. You... I-I-you know, if I have grass or alcohol or anything I get unbearably wonderful. I get too, too wonderful for words. You know, I don't-I don't know why you have to, uh, get high every time we make love.
Person2: It relaxes me.
Person1: Oh, you-you have to be artificially relaxed before we can go to bed?
Person2: Well, what's the difference, anyway?
Person1: Well, I'll give you a shot of sodium pentothal. You can sleep through it.
Person2: Oh, come on, look who's talking. You've been seeing a psychiatrist for fifteen years.  You should smoke some o' this. You'd be off the couch in no time.
Person1: Oh, come, you don't need that.

Person1: Oh, Judy!! When he had all her money, and the freedom and the power...  he ditched you? What a shame! But he knew he was safe. You couldn't talk. Didn't he give you anything?
Person2: Some money.
Person1: And the necklace. Carlotta's necklace. That was your mistake, Judy. One shouldn't keep souvenirs of a killing. You shouldn't have been that sentimental.

Person1: No, see, Neil, if you're messing with one of my friends, then you're messing with me.
Person2: Don't do that.
Person1: What are you going to do? Hm?
Person2: If you hit me...
Person1: Yeah?
Person2: ... my manager will slap an assault charge on your rear faster than you can say AA, okay?
Person1: Your manager?
Person2: Yeah, man, my manager and my lawyer.
Person1: Well, just, you know, have 'em call me. Y-you know where to find me, right?
Person2: Oh, yeah, drunk on the corner, man. Hey, why don't you buy another beer. It's on me, okay?

Person1: There must be some other way out.
Person2: Well, until that's found, I think it's a good idea we all stick together.  Or wouldn't that fit into your plans, baby?

Person1: I'll go first.
Person2: No -- I will.
Person1: I stood up first.
Person2: That doesn't matter.
Person1: You always get to go first.

Person1: Mom, please
Person2: You'll have to watch Jamie tonight.
Person1: Not tonight. I've got that date with Brady. You know how important that is.
Person2: Well tonight is very important for your father and me.
Person1: Can't you find somebody else?
Person2: Its too late.
Person1: What am I supposed to tell Brady? Sorry, but I've got to baby-sit my foster sister, go and have fun by yourself.
Person2: Its not exactly the end of the world, for goodness sake

Person1: I'll drive you, darlin'. You've got no business behind the wheel of an automobile. You don't think about what you're doing and you'll run into a telephone pole.
Person2: I think about what I'm doing all the time, and I've got as much business behind the wheel of an automobile as anybody. Besides, I want you to stay and help Rose with the dishes, the poor girl isn't feeling well.
Person1: All right, darlin'.

Person1: Hold me, Don.
Person2: Don? Where is he?
Person1: HELP HIM!! Promise me you'll help him!
Person2: I promise, Dorothy. I promise.
Person1: Hold me. I'M FALLING!

Person1: Dan!  The spare costumes!  I can't believe you kept them.
Person2: Me neither.  Mine barely even fits.  The thing is, I try to remember why we did it, and I can't.  Helping people, or righting wrongs, or trying to save the world . . . I don't know.  It all seems so abstract.

Person1: I'm on the move -
Person2: Your girl works in there ...
Person1: Not my girl anymore
Person2: Yet your still here ... I gave you 24 hours, 24 hours ago ...
Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Honestly? I want to - once every few months - get into my car. Pack a lunch. And drive on up to Chino. On visiting day. Bring you some magazines. Maybe some almond clusters. And see you all bright and shiny in your orange jumpsuit. That's what I want ...

Person1: ...all train compartments smell vaguely of shit.  It gets so you don't mind it.  That's the worst thing that I can confess.  You know how long it took me to get there? A long time.  When you die you're going to regret the things you don't do.  You think you're queer...? I'm going to tell you something. We're all queer.  You think that you're a thief?  So what?  You get befuddled by a middle-class morality...?  Get shut of it.  Shut it out.  You cheated on your wife...?  You did it, live with it.  You fuck little girls, so be it. There's an absolute morality?  May be.  And then what?  If you think there is, then be that thing.  Bad people go to hell?  I don't think so.  If you think that, act that way.  A hell exists on earth?  Yes. I won't live in it.  That's me. You ever take a dump made you feel you'd just slept for twelve hours...?
Person2: Did I...?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: I don't know.

Person1: She's got information inside of her.  I need you to get it out.
Person2: No.  No way.  I wouldn't even know where to begin!  Those thoughts about my cousin Elena -- they were just thoughts. I would never --
Person1: C'mon, Rufus, you've been busted twice for felony hacking.
Person2: So?
Person1: So now I need you to hack into her.

Person1: And I can't say his name without laughing I want to eat him up. I want to say goodbye to every bad thought I ever had about relationships.  I mean, I crave this guy... and yet... why... why did I have that affair this weekend?  Does that mean I'm not in love with my boyfriend?
Person2: I think you'll know when you see him at the gate.
Person1: It's the death rattle of my singlehood, right? Because I finally see the white picket fence looming and I love it/hate it/love it/hate it/ love it... you're right, I'll know when I see him. Why is it so easy to talk with you?!  Tell me about your fiancee.

Person1: Hey, I've got a great compliment for you.
Person2: You know what? I...
Person1: Just let me talk.  I'm the only one on the face of the earth who realizes that you're the greatest woman on earth. I'm the only one who appreciates how amazing you are in every single thing you do -- in every single thought you have... in how you are with Spencer -- Spence...  ... in how you say what you mean and how you almost always mean something that's all about being straight and good...

Person1: Hey....I was just telling everyone about how I was gonna bring this girl for you but you wouldn't let me do it.
Person2: Hello everyone.

Person1: Edie, listen, stay out of this mess. Quit tryin' to ask things about Joey. It ain't safe for you.
Person2: Why worry about me? You're the one who says only look out for yourself.
Person1: Okay, get in hot water. But don't come hollerin' to me when you get burned.
Person2: Why should I come hollering to you at all?
Person1: Because... because...  Listen Edie, don't get sore now but I think we're getting in love with each other.
Person2: I can't let myself fall in love with you.
Person1: That goes double for me.

Person1: You're hitting on me?
Person2: You're a beautiful girl, Elle.
Person1: So everything you just said --
Person2: I'm a man who knows what I want.

Person1: He hasn't said one word to me.
Person2: Maybe he's just shy.
Person1: My date always pays more attention to you than to me.
Person2: Frida, I don't mean this as a criticism, but you might not want to talk about PMS around men.
Person1: Sorry. It's just so bad lately. You're so lucky you never get PMS.
Person2: I get a little bloated sometimes.
Person1: I'd kill for just a little bloated.

Person1: It's all right.  Danny always said I see things with my emotions instead of my eyes.
Person2: It's not your fault, Rafe.  The letter I wrote you, they --
Person1: Don't worry about that.  Guys away from home, lonely, good-hearted women try to cheer them up.
Person2: It's not that I didn't mean everything I wrote.  It's just that -- I thought you were dead.  And now --

Person1: Rick, I want to talk to you.
Person2: Ah, Cole.  I don't remember ordering an asshole from room service.

Person1: Do you have a note to corroborate these claims?
Person2: Um, well...
Person1: Are you lying to me?
Person2: Well...
Person1: What did we say about lying?
Person2: I'm not lying.
Person1: You know that no one likes a liar, right?
Person2: I said I'm not lying.

Person1: You will not be unaware of the threat now posed by Republicanism.
Person2: Why do you think I keep her here?
Person1: Ah, but therein lies the paradox.  It is her very isolation that encourages the malcontents.  The longer she is away, the stronger they become; and who, honestly, can promise security against that?  However many doors you lock, someone will always get in. Even here.

Person1: You set up the line-up.
Person2: Mr. Soze made a few calls, yes. You were not to be released until I came to see you. It seems Mr. Keaton's attorney, Ms. Finneran, was a bit too effective in expediting his release. Holding the rest of you became a moot point.
Person1: What about Redfoot?
Person2: Mr. Redfoot knew nothing. Mr. Soze rarely                 t works with the same people for very long, and they never know who they're working for. One cannot be betrayed if one has no people.

Person1: I don't got any money... for fixin' me up and all.
Person2: Don't need none.
Person1: Then I better be on my way. Don't wanna put you out no more.
Person2: Think it'd be best if you stayed put while we talk.
Person1: Naw'sir... I gotta be on my way.
Person2: Best try gettin' ya wits about you 'fore you try to...

Person1: Jesus! Listen to this one: "Do you remember me? Airport shuttle, June 7th. You: striking redhead with yellow dress, pearl necklace, brown shoes. I was the bookish fellow in the green cardigan who helped you find your contact lens. Am I crazy, or did we have a moment?"
Person2: God, that's so pathetic. I bet she didn't even notice him.
Person1: I know. And he's like psychotically obsessing over every little detail.
Person2: We should call him and pretend to be the redhead.
Person1: Oh, we totally have to.

Person1: It doesn't matter. Your life is hard enough.
Person2: You're a liar.
Person1: You know I'm not.
Person2: YOU'RE A LIAR!
Person1: Look at me.

Person1: I've been asking you for weeks to spend some quality time together.
Person2: I've been swamped with work, Lana.
Person1: If you really cared, you would make time, no matter how busy.
Person2: I do care, but I also need to handle my responsibilities. Let's find a balance.

Person1: You stay out of this, Glinda, or I'll fix you as well!
Person2: Oh, rubbish!  You have no power here. Be gone, before somebody drops a house on you, too.
Person1: Very well -- I'll bide my time -- and as for you, my fine lady, it's true, I can't attend to you here and now as I'd like, but just try to stay out of my way....

Person1: Calvin, I wish you would have at least let me do the dishes. It's not going to be that easy getting all that dried- on food off my nice plates.
Person2: I just hope those plates aren't radioactive by tomorrow morning.
Person1: Cheese is particularly troublesome.
Person2: Worse than your Kraft Holiday dip?
Person1: Oh, much worse. But not as bad as that Mexican Jumping Bean dip. You remember that?
Person2: Yeah, yeah. Okay.  Give me the roast and watch your step.  I'll come back for the radio.

Person1: No. I will not betray my friends.
Person2: They're not your friends... they've held you back... kept you from your destiny...
Person1: That is not true. They have tried to help me.
Person2: Have they given you what I have given you? Did they even try?
Person1: I... do not want this...

Person1: Apart from that, you look pretty chipper for a man who's two thousand and thirty one years old.  I read the clocks. They bear out Hasslein's hypothesis. We've been away from Earth for two thousand years, give or take a decade.  Still can't accept it, huh?
Person2: long pause) You know it.
Person1: Because time has wiped out everyone and everything you cared for -- they're dust.
Person2: Prove it. If we can't get back, it's still just a theory.
Person1: It's a fact, Landon. Buy it. You'll sleep better.

Person1: I can almost feel your doubt about what I'm saying, Mary.
Person2: I can't give up looking for her, Mrs. Redi, no matter what you're hinting at.
Person1: I have no intention whatsoever of hinting. Your sister, Mary, is a murderess. She killed Irving August -- stabbed him out of fright when he discovered where she was hiding.
Person2: I don't believe it.
Person1: I had to help get rid of the body. You saw it on the subway. And I warn you, Mary -- go back -- you don't know what you're doing, or what dreadful things you might bring about by looking for your sister. You go back to school - - go back and forget Jacqueline.

Person1: Why did Gregory ask me out? I mean he's cute -- he probably just wants to pitch his screenplay idea.
Person2: Maybe he likes you, ever think of that? It's good for you to go out -- get your mind off Mark.
Person1: You're so lucky you have George and don't need to go on dates anymore.
Person2: What I really hated about dating was the lines guys used to get into my apartment. "Can I use your phone?" "How about a nightcap?" "I want to meet your cat." And my all-time favorite, the old standby, "I have to use your bathroom."
Person1: Maybe they have to pee.
Person2: Are you kidding? He might as well say, "Can I date rape you?"
Person1: I never thought of it like that. I never know what to do on dates. Do guys still pay?
Person2: They better. Of course, trouble is, you never know what they'll expect for it. You gotta know what to order, and what you're willing to do. Like if a guy spends a fortune on you, he's gonna feel like you owe him something.

Person1: Mr. Caiman, you're married.
Person2: And you're beautiful...
Person1: Mr. Caiman...
Person2: Call me Charlie.
Person1: Mr. Caiman, I've been doing extra research for you after hours and weekends for nearly a year. And I've never asked for anything but this job is really important to me. I'm too old to be an assistant anymore. I need to know this job is going someplace.
Person2: So have dinner with me tonight.

Person1: My Lady Cosgrove's relationship with me was a singular one.  Her life was passed in a series of crack-brained sort of alternation between love and hatred for me.  We would quarrel for a fortnight, then we should be friends for a month together sometimes.  One day, I was joking her, and asking her whether she would take the water again, whether she had found another lover, and so forth.  She suddenly burst out into tears, and, after a while, said to me.
Person2: Roderick, you know well enough that I have never loved but you!  Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy? Ever so angry, but the least offer of good-will on your part did not bring me to your side?  Did I not give a sufficient proof of my affection for you in bestowing one of the finest fortunes of England upon you?  Have I repined or rebuked you for the way you have wasted it? No, I loved you too much and too fondly; I have always loved you. From the first moment I saw you, I saw your bad qualities, and trembled at your violence; but I could not help loving you.  I married you, though I knew I was sealing my own fate in doing so, and in spite of reason and duty.  What sacrifice do you want from me?  I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or, if not, that at least, you will gently us me.

Person1: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.

Person1: I've got you, Dr. Evil!

You're thin, I'm about forty pounds overweight. OK, we are different, I'm not making a very good point. However, isn't it ironic, Mr. Powers, that the very things you stand for-- swinging, free love, parties, distrust of authority- are all now, in the Nineties, considered to be... evil? Maybe we have more in common than you care to admit.
Person1: No, man, what we swingers were rebelling against were uptight squares like you, whose bag was money and world domination. We were innocent, man. If we'd known the consequences of our sexual liberation, we would have done things differently, but the spirit would have remained the same.  It's freedom, man.
Person2: Your freedom has cause more pain and suffering in the world than any plan I ever dreamed of. Face it, freedom failed.

Person1: Addison wants me to play it.

Person1: That won't be necessary. Addison knows how Margo happen to miss that performance - how I happened to know she'd miss it in time to call him and notify every paper in town...  ... it's quite a story. Addison could make quite a thing of it - imagine how snide and vicious he could get and still write nothing but the truth. I had a time persuading him...  ... you'd better sit down. You look a bit wobbly.  If I play "Cora," Addison will never tell what happened - in or out of print. A simple exchange of favors. And I'm so happy I can do something for you - at long last...  Your friendship with Margo - your deep, close friendship - what would happen to it, do you think, if she knew the chap trick you'd played on her - for my benefit? And you and Lloyd - how long, even in the Theater, before people forgot what happened - and trusted you again?  No... it would be so much easier on everyone concerned, if I were to play "Cora." And so much better theater, too...

So try to remember when you and he - when -- well I don't know, there was that dumper once, he sounded like that dumper --  Dumpers; they get their kicks beating you up. A man hired me once, then tried to really kill me - that'd be about two years ago.

Person1: My generosity is not so large as that.

Person1: Yes... the Beautiful Carlotta... the Sad Carlotta...

Person1: It was hers. It was built for her. Many years ago.
Person2: By whom?
Person1: By... no... the name I do not remember. A rich man, a powerful man.  It is not an unusual story. She came from somewhere small, to the south of the city... some say from a mission settlement... young, yes; very young.  And she was found singing and dancing in a cabaret by the man... wait... wait... Ives! His name was Ives!  Yes. And he took her and built for her this great house in the Western Addition... and there was a child. Yes. This was it. The child.

Now all I need is your credit card number.

Person1: After I left...when I was in California, I began to think, what kind of mother was I that I could walk out on my own child. It got to where I couldn't tell anybody about Billy--I couldn't stand that look in their faces when I said he wasn't living with me.  Finally it seemed like the most important thing in the world to come back here and prove to Billy and to me and to the world how much I loved him...And I did ...And I won.  Only...it was just another "should."  ...Sitting in that courtroom. Hearing everything you did, everything you went through... Something happened.  I guess it doesn't matter how much I love him, or how much you love him. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for Billy.  I don't know, maybe that's all love is anyway... Ted, I think Billy should stay with you...

Person1: Hello.  Hello, Leon.

Person2: Yeah.  So how are you?

Person2: Yeah... I know.
Person1: I don't know what I'm gonna do... you know.  Boy... I'm dying.
Person2: What?  What are you talking about? You are dying?  Did you ever listen to yourself when you say that?
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: What do you mean... what am I talking about?  Do you realize that you say that to me every day of your life?  I am dying.  Do you know... do you realize the death that you are spreading around to the people who are around you?
Person1: Now don't give me that deep shit now.  Don't start with that shit.
Person2: No really... I don't think that you realize what it means.  The things that you do, Sonny.  You put a gun to somebody's head...
Person1: I don't know what I'm doing.
Person2: Yeah... obviously you don't... when you put a gun to somebody's head... and you say go to sleep so that it won't hurt when I pull the trigger. Death?  Don't talk about death to me.  I have been living with death for the last six months.  Why do you think I'm in the hospital?  I take a handful of pills to get away from you.  And then here I am out of the hospital talking to you on the phone... again.  I have no friends left.  No job.  I can't live.  I have to live with people. This death business... I'm sorry!
Person1: I'm not on the phone to talk to you about that.  Well, I don't know what to say, Leon.  When you gimme that... when you hit me with that shit.  I mean, what am I supposed to say?
Person2: I'm sorry...
Person1: I told you.  That I got a lot of pressures.  You said to me that you needed money, and I knew that you needed money!  I saw you there lying in the hospital like that... and I said... shit, man, I got to get this guy some money.
Person2: But I didn't ask you to go rob a bank.
Person1: All right.  I know you didn't ask me.  You didn't ask me but I did it.
Person2: Well...
Person1: I did it on my own.  I did this all on my own.  I ain't laying it on anybody.  Nothing on anybody.  I'll tell you something, though, it's about time that I squared away my accounts... you know.  I am squaring away my accounts with life.  Maye this whole thing is gonna end, somehow.  Maybe it'll just end! Maybe I'll just close my eyes and the whole thing will be over. That would be all right too!  I said... I thought I would square it away with you... you know?  That I would get you down here and that I would say so long to you... or, if you wanted... you know, to take a trip...
Person2: What trip?
Person1: I'm getting out of here, man.  I'm not going to stay here and I'm not giving up.  I mean, huh, they're going to kill me, anyway.  So forget it!  But, if I can get out of this... I am going to get out. And, how I'm going to do it is to get a jet out of here and I'm flying the fuck out... That's all, Leon.  If you want to come with me, then you're entitled... you can come.  You're free to do what you want.
Person2: I'm free to do what I want?  And you think I would want to go with you some place on a plane?  Where? Where ya going?
Person1: I gotta jet coming here and we're gonna try to get outta this thing.  And we're gonna go, man!
Person2: You're crazy.
Person1: That's it.
Person2: You're really crazy.
Person1: I know!
Person2: Where you gonna go?
Person1: Who knows?  I think we're gonna go ... we worked it out to Algeria.  So, I don't know.  So I'll go to Algeria.
Person2: Why you going to Algeria?
Person1: Huh ... I don't know.  They got Howard Johnson's there.  I don't know why I'm going there for.
Person2: Howard Johnson's... you're warped. You know that?  You're really warped!
Person1: I know that.  I'm warped... I'm warped!
Person2: God, Algeria!  Do you know there's a bunch of... they walk around there... God!  People walk around with masks and things on their heads.  They're a bunch of crazy people there.
Person1: What am I supposed to do?
Person2: I don't know... you could have picked a better place.
Person1: Denmark?  Sweden?
Person2: I like that... yeah!

Person1: I'm going to tell you a secret now, Elaine.  Simone is not a real person.  I invented her.
Person2: Every actor is an invention, Viktor.  Don't embarrass yourself. No one's denying that you discovered Simone.  But it's like finding a diamond in the desert. Anyone can trip over it, but it's not the finder who sparkles.
Person1: -- No, no, I didn't trip over her. You don't understand --
Person2: -- You just got lucky that she's loyal enough to stay with you. Maybe she's staying out of pity, who knows?  She certainly doesn't need you.  Some people even say you're holding her back.
Person1: Who says that -- ?  -- Never mind.  You have to listen to me, Elaine.  Simone is thin air, pixels, molded by me from a mathematical equation.  I inherited it from a madman -- I can show you --
Person2: How much wine have you had?
Person1: -- She's a figment of my own imagination.  I, Viktor Taransky, have perpetrated the greatest hoax, the greatest sleight-of-hand, sleight-of-mouth, sleight-of- sleight in entertainment history! And still no one appreciates me, recognizes what I've done -- even you.
Person2: You're drunker than I thought.  Are you doing that again?
Person1: No!  Whatever talent Simone has comes from me -- me!  Me!  I swear, as God is my judge.  You don't know what I've been through.  Tens of thousands of mind-numbing hours in front of that screen, nights without end, and look what it's cost me.  Why do you think I've been wearing these?  I may have done irreparable harm to my eyesight, and why?  To extract and refine the infinite nuances of a human being -- a human soul.  Don't you see?  I made Simone!

Person2: Stage-struck kid... she's a young lady - of qualities. And I'll have you know I'm fed up with both the young lady and her qualities! Studying me as if - as if I were a play or a set of blueprints! How I walk, talk, think, eat, sleep!

Person1: Mad! Darling, there are certain characteristics for which you are famous - on stage and off. I love you for some of them - and in spite of others. I haven't let those become too important to me. They're part of your equipment for getting along in what is laughably called out environment - you've got to keep your teeth sharp. All right. But you will not sharpen them on me - or on Eve...
Person2: What about her teeth? What about her fangs?
Person1: She hasn't cut them yet, and you know it! So when you start judging an idealistic dreamy-eyed kid by the barroom, Benzedrine standards of this megalomaniac society - I won't have it! Eve Harrington has never by word, look, thought or suggestion indicated anything to me but her adoration for you and her happiness at our being in love! And to intimate anything else doesn't spell jealousy to me - it spells a paranoic insecurity that you should be ashamed of!

Person1: Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of your life.
Person2: But what about us?
Person1: We'll always have Paris. We didn't have, we'd lost it, until you came to Casablanca. We got it back last night.
Person2: And I said I would never leave you.
Person1: And you never will. But I've got a job to do, too. Where I'm going you can't follow. What I've got to do you can't be any part of. Ilsa, I'm no good at being noble, but it doesn't take much to see that the problems of three little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. Someday you'll understand that. Now, now...

Person1: All right, Johnnie, you want to play it this way, I can play it this way. You want to know who made a mistake, why don't you open the case.
Person2: Caesar ...
Person1: Shut up, Violet!  This is between me and Johnnie.

Person1: Sounds to me like somebody needs to hit the gym.
Person2: Excuse me?
Person1: I heard you strain when you put the milk in the bag. That milk only weighs about seven pounds.
Person2: I didn't strain. I sighed.
Person1: I don't think so. That was a grunt; a deep inhalation of oxygen to aid in the stretching of muscles. I'm a trainer. I know what that sound signifies. You're out of shape.
Person2: I don't think so.
Person1: Oh, I do. You made the same noise when you reached across the counter for my cash. Your muscles are thin and sadly underutilized.
Person2: They are not.
Person1: Yes, they are. You're out of shape.
Person2: What are you talking about? There's no fat on this body.
Person1: No fat, but no tone either. You don't get enough exercise.

Person1: Christ, you scared the shit out of me.
Person2: Aw, you ain't seen nothing yet.
Person1: Is your brother ready to go?
Person2: Oh... yeah, he already left. We'll wait inside, come on.
Person1: He left!
Person2: Yeah, come on.

Person1: Zorg. Jean-Baptiste Emmanuel Zorg... nice to see you again
Person2: I remember you now..the so called art dealer.
Person1: I'm glad you got your memory back, Father... Because you're going to need it... Where are the stones?
Person2: ...Why on earth do the stones interest you?
Person1: Personally, they are of no interest to me, I'd rather sell weapons..but I have a customer... so tell me...
Person2: Even it I did know where the stones were I would never tell somebody like you.
Person1: Why?  What's wrong with me?
Person2: ...I'm a priest! I'm here to serve life, All you want to do is destroy it.
Person1: Ah, Father... You are so wrong. Let me explain...

Person1: Mrs. Parker, was Kristen acting different? Did you notice anything strange before she made the attempt?
Person2: Kristen specializes in strangeness.  I've spent thousands on psychiatirists.
Person1: Did she always have nightmares?
Person2: They've gotten worse since I took away her credit cards.
Person1: I'm serious.
Person2: Look, Miss Thompson, I don't know what you want from me.
Person1: Just some answers.  There are other kids involved, its not just Kristen.  All good kids, smark kids.
Person2: I'm sorry to hear that, but you're the experts on this, not me.  If I had any insights, believe me, I'd share them with you.
Person1: I'm sure you would.
Person2: Now if you'll excuse me, I have to get to the club.
Person1: I'll need to take her things.
Person2: The maid packed a suitcase.  Teresa!  Teresa?
Person1: I'll get it.  Please, I don't mind.
Person2: First door up the stairs.

Person1: And were you never ambitious, Excellency?  Or is ambition only a virtue among the nobles, a fault for the rest of us?
Person2: If you won't accept our proposal, we'll simply find someone who will.

Person1: Can I give you a hand, beautiful?
Person2: I'm just going to my car?
Person1: That's right on my way.
Person2: My mother told me never to accept offers from strangers.
Person1: My name is Bobby.  Now I'm not a stranger anymore.  See how easy it is for us to get to know each other, beautiful?
Person2: Do you have to call me that?
Person1: I don't know your real name.
Person2: Maybe I don't want you to.

Person1: We're all dying from the start.  I just got picked for Advanced Placement.
Person2: You lied to me!
Person1: I would have lied to me if I thought I'd believe it.
Person2: This was all for your sake, wasn't it? Having me here?  Trying to get me to like you.
Person1: I never tried to get you to like me.  I tried to get you to love me.
Person2: Well, congratulations!  You pulled it off!

Person1: What about you, Karl? Do you want to stay here?
Person2: I don't reckon you have to go with women to be a daddy to a boy.  You've been real square dealin' with me. The Bible says two men ort not lay together. But I'll bet you the Good Lord wouldn't send nobody like you to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades.  That boy lives inside of his own heart. Hits an awful big place. You take care of that boy.

Person1: We're alike. We are hunters. We have the gift. It's ancient times all over again. We stand between order and chaos. I need help. I can't carry on alone.
Person2: Maybe you should back off.
Person1: This guy, Zero, he drifts around, that's how they all start, drifting around, their minds filling up with fantasies. He thinks he's real smart, laughs at us, laughs at his victims. But he has left a trail, and the trail is somewhere in those names. You know how to reach me.  Take my advice, when dealing with these FBI tight-asses, go by the book. That's what I did.
Person2: You? You went by the book?
Person1: Yeah, problem was, I had the only copy. See ya.

Person1: Who do you think I'm doing this for? I'm doing this for you!
Person2: Bullshit! It's about you! About you deciding! About you always being right! You always getting everything your way, controlling everybody -- like we work for you or something!
Person1: I don't believe this!
Person2: You just want to get away from Daddy and you're using me to do it!
Person1: That's not true! Whatever problems your father and I are having, have nothing to do with this.
Person2: You're amazing! You act like I don't live in that house! Don't you think I hear the two of you!? Don't you think I can tell what's going on? I'm not five years old, Mom!  You want to divorce Daddy and Daddy doesn't want to.
Person1: Did he tell you that?
Person2: He doesn't have to! It's, like, so obvious you can't stand him.
Person1: That's not true!
Person2: Then why do you want to leave?
Person1: It's... it's not that simple to explain. I know you think it is, but it's not. The truth is, I don't really know what I want to do. I don't have all the answers.
Person2: No, you just act like you do.

Person1: Is that my -- scenario?  Tell me.
Person2: They'd frame him.
Person1: He's out of prison?
Person2: They're already watching you. If they had to, they'd give him this drug that mimics an alcoholic blackout. He'd wake up not even remembering his "act of revenge."

Person1: You know what I'd like? A clear, empty sky... and a plane, and us in it... and somewhere a private island for sale, where we can run around without our... shoes on.  And the wherewithal to buy what I'd like.  Mary, you want to cut this off, go out and find yourself someone available.
Person2: I'm thinking of it.
Person1: How can you even think a thing like that!
Person2: Don't miss your plane.
Person1: Hey, we can leave together can't we?
Person2: I'm late... and you have to put your shoes on.

Person1: This has been a good year.
Person2: Jesse, we're outlaws.
Person1: And we're good at it.
Person2: It got to you, didn't it. All the killing in the war. You need it now.
Person1: You've killed your fair share of men.
Person2: If I could go back to farming --
Person1: That's a lie. You could've bought a dozen farms with the money we've stolen.
Person2: I can't quit and leave you alone. I can't quit until you quit. Ma would've wanted it that way.
Person1: We're doing this for Ma.
Person2: Maybe it started out that way. But now...
Person1: What do you want me to say, Frank? I was killing men when I was fifteen. I like getting shot at. I like riding out of town with a posse at my back. This is a helluva better life than farming.
Person2: A better life than the one you could have had with Zee?

Person1: That's him. Let him in.
Person2: Wait a minute--Jim--you didn't ask Smith over here!
Person1: What do you think?
Person2: Jim, you can't come here and pull that steamroller stuff. Your methods won't do here. This boy is a Senator, however it happened, he's a Senator. This is Washington.
Person1: Steamroller stuff, Joe? My methods don't go in Washington? They've done pretty well by now, haven't they?
Person2: Oh, Jim, that's beside the point. This boy's different. He's honest and beside he thinks the world of me. We can't do this to him.
Person1: Well, what do you want me to do? Stand around like you chump and let that drooling infant wrap that Willet Creek Dam appropriation around my neck. Either he falls in line with us and behaves himself or I'll break him so wide open they'll never be able to find the pieces.
Person2: Jim, I won't stand for it.
Person1: You won't stand for it?
Person2: I don't want any part of crucifying this boy.
Person1: Oh, I see. Out steamroller methods are getting too hard to your sensitive soul, is that it, Joe? The Silver Knight is getting to big for us. My methods have been all right for the past twenty years, Joe, since I picked you out of a fly-specked hole in the wall and blew you up to look like a Senator, and now you can't stand it. Well, maybe you won't have to stand it, Joe. Maybe we can fix it so you and your Boy Ranger can go home together.
Person2: Jim, you don't have to--
Person1: Oh, it's all right--it's all right. It seems a shame, though, to part company like this after all these years, especially now with a national convention coming up. Joe, I've put everything I have behind you. And so did all of our friends, but I guess we'll survive. We'll just have to find somebody else that's got a little more sense, that's all. In the meantime, you explain to Mr. Smith about Willet Dam. It's your bill-- it's your reputation, and if he can't find enough facts to break you with, you just send him to me and I'll give him a couple of good ones. I'm taking the next plane home.
Person2: Jim, it's just that I like the kid-- I don't want to see you get too rough on him.
Person1: I'm glad to see you come to your senses. You had me scared there for a minute, thought.  Let him in.

Person1: Having you here, Anna, firmly establishes what I've long suspected, that we really are the most desperate hot of under-achievers.
Person2: Shame!
Person1: I'm not saying it's a bad thing, in fact, I think it's something we should take pride in.  I'm going to give the last brownie as a prize to the saddest act here.

Person1: You too are lonely.
Person2: I ache with it.
Person1: Let me comfort you.
Person2: I cannot take comfort when she has none.
Person1: Then give me comfort. Sleep with me tonight.
Person2: I cannot betray my bride.
Person1: One night is no betrayal. Have pity on me.  Please, I beg you, do not refuse me. You do not know the price.

Person1: You didn't happen to be going to Worth's place, did you?
Person2: No, sir, I'm sure it wasn't there.
Person1: You used to go to Worth's place a whole lot. What makes you sure it wasn't there?
Person2: Well, maybe it was. I don't remember.  You got to do something for me, I can't stand it any longer -- I can't!

Person1: Look we gave you what you asked for.  It checks out didn't it?! What more do you want from us!
Person2: I told you not to try anything smart!  I guess you're too much of a maverick to follow a simple order!  And that's just too bad for all of you now, isn't it?
Person1: Look you said it doesn't matter to you anyway!  Why do you want to kill more innocent people!  Why!

Person1: We lost cousins, friends.  We will wash this in blood.
Person2: If you want to keep your head on your shoulders, you'll do as I say.

Person1: You taking sides against me, now, Frank?
Person2: No, I --

Person1: Let me tell him.  Let him decide.
Person2: You're not gonna see him again.
Person1: What... what makes you think you can order me around?!
Person2: Maybe I'm not making myself clear. You're probably the first girl Billy-Boy's ever fallen in love with, and I know for sure you're the first he's slept with.  So, how's he gonna feel...  ... when he finds out that the only first he is for you is the first guy who didn't have to pull out at the last second to get his close-up?

Person1: This is your bed. You may leave your things in that cabinet.
Person2: Yes, ma'am...
Person1: Please use your time to familiarize yourself with your new home and if there is anything you need to know, don't hesitate to ask us.
Person2: Now that you mention it, I sure would like to call my aunt up in Portland and tell 'er where I am so she can come visit me.
Person1: All in good time, Mister McMurphy. All in good time.
Person2: Yes, ma'am.
Person1: Good. Now if you'll just go along with Mister Washington, he'll see that you're properly oriented.

Person1: Okay, Wilhelm, go home now. Go home and think about these past twelve years.
Person2: I don't understand what you mean.
Person1: No, that's your problem, Wilhelm. You understand nothing. We'll call you. Go!

Person1: ... looks like you grown another inch... but you don't look so hot, getting bags under your eyes, starting to look old like me.
Person2: Ah, I had a tough day. Some jerk D.K'd me and I gotta cover his loss.
Person1: Speak English will ya.
Person2: D.K. -- didn't know -- who I was when the options he bought took a bath. He reneged on me.
Person1: I told you not to go into that racket. You could've been a doctor or a lawyer,
Person2: Coulda been a contender.
Person1: you coulda stayed at Bluestar and been a supervisor in instead of going customer relations by now, 'stead of going off and bein' a salesman.
Person2: Look Dad, I'm not a salesman. How many times I gotta tell you I'm an account executive, and pretty soon I'm going to the investment banking side of the firm.
Person1: You get on the phone and ask strangers for their money, right? You're a salesman.
Person2: Dad, it takes time. You gotta build a customer list. I'm doing it. I could make more money in one year as a broker than five years at the airline.
Person1: I don't get it, you get a scholarship to NYU, you get 35,000 the first year, and 50 last year, where the hell is it?
Person2: 50 K don't get you to first base in the Big Apple, Dad, not any more. I pay 40% in taxes, I got a rent of 15,000, I got school loans, car loans, food, park my car costs me 3 bills a month, I need good suits, that's $500 a pop, shoes...
Person1: So come home and live rent free, 'stead of that cockroach palace you live in. $50,000 Jesus Christ, the world is off its rocker. I made $37,000 last year and you...
Person2: It's Queens, Dad and a 5% mortgage and you rent the top room--I gotta live in Manhattan to be a player, Dad. There's no nobility in poverty anymore, y'know. One day you're going to be proud of me, you'll see...
Person1: It's yourself you've got to be proud of, Huckleberry, how much ya need?
Person2: Can you spare three hundred? Pay you back next month, promise.

Person1: Not now, I'm talking to the press. Claire!
Person2: What?  I have a five-o'clock plane to catch.
Person1: I, uh...  I've always thought so...  Well, you just get an idea, and try to find the best way to express it in pictorial form.  I've written a letter to the studio and to SAG protesting...  Bill. get a copy of that letter...!  I just wanted to tell you that I am past chagrined, I'm mortified at the way you were spoken to...
Person2: I...
Person1: An artist of your caliber...
Person2: I'm only trying to...
Person1: I know what you are, I am so sorry that you...when I read that script I said there's only one person to play that part.
Person2: The minute I read that script I said...
Person1: I know...
Person2: ...she works with animals, she...
Person1: ...yes...
Person2: ...she has a home...
Person1: ...I know, I'm so...because I said yes, a woman who...the...the community respects her.  Please don't go.  Please don't go.  What can I do but beseech you...?  Trauma, toil...when are we free of them...?  When...?
Person2: He treated me as if I were a child...
Person1: Claire. As an interpretive artist to a creative artist:  Stay with me.  I need you.  We start to shoot tomorrow and then it belongs to us.  Stay.  Stay.  Tonight...when...  When they've gone.  Let's talk.  Let's really talk.  We could, we'll have dinner, we'll...a bottle of some bad red wine, we'll get spaghetti, and we'll...
Person2: I'm sorry Walt -- it's gone beyond that.

Person1: Sit, sit...  Would you like one?
Person2: No, Mikhi, I wouldn't.  Since I won't speak your language, and you can't speak mine, English will do nicely.
Person1: Whatever you wish...  This has all been a terrible mistake, Gregor.  I wanted to play straight with you, but Edvard insisted we try and kill you.
Person2: Edvard said the same thing about you before he died.
Person1: I'm shocked, shocked to think that you'd believe him.
Person2: Enough!

Person1: Now do you want the good news first or the bad news?
Person2: You better start making sense!
Person1: Ok, I will.  The bad news is the ship is history.  Life support will last another 36 hours, maybe.
Person2: Then we've got to get to the lifepods!
Person1: I'd advise you to shut up and let me finish Taylor.  You needn't worry about the lifepods because they're all gone, jettisoned. Save for one.

Person1: ...and her heart stopped and she wasn't getting oxygen.
Person2: That's right.
Person1: And what did your team do...
Person2: Well, we...
Person1: ...You brought thirty years of medical experience to bear.  Isn't that what you did?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: ...A patient riddled with complications, questionable information on her, on her admitting form...
Person2: ...We did everything we could...
Person1: ...to save her and to save the baby.  Is that...
Person2: Yes!
Person1: You reached down into death.  Now, isn't that right?
Person2: My God, we tried to save her...You can't know...You can't know...
Person1: Tell us.

Person1: I'm fully amenable to that discussion.
Person2: I mean, we're having a lot of fun now -- but things are gonna be different when I'm at Harvard. Law school is a completely different world. I need to be serious.
Person1: Of course.
Person2: My family expects a lot from me. And I expect a lot from me. I plan on running for office some day.
Person1: And I fully support that.
Person2: But the thing is, if I'm gonna be a senator by the time I'm thirty -- I can't keep dicking around.
Person1: I completely agree.
Person2: That's why I think it's time for us to --

Person1: No. Not tomorrow, not next week, Marry me today.
Person2: Why the change? What about your work?
Person1: It was misguided and pointless. Is your answer yes?
Person2: It is
Person1: We'll leave this afternoon, right after the ceremony. Pack only what you need.
Person2: Does this have something to do with that man you saw?
Person1: Yes. We're in danger here. Every moment we stay.
Person2: Victor, tell me why! Trust me!
Person1: I do. But you must trust me for now.

Person1: Do yourself a favor, Norman.  Are you listening?  Don't tell anyone what you just told me.
Person2: C'mon, Beth -- that report's like the blind leading the blind.
Person1: Because when we get down there --
Person2: Wait -- down where?
Person1: To the spacecraft.  To investigate.
Person2: Underwater?
Person1: What do you expect?  For them to bring it up here?
Person2: We can't go down there.  We're not prepared.  That deep?  That takes years of training, Beth.  We're just scientists.  Lab scietists.  We wear ties and lab coats to work -- not oxygen tanks.
Person1: Well, you must have realized the chances an encounter like this would happen here.  In the ocean.  70 percent of the earth's surface is water, Norman.  That's first grade geography.
Person2: It never occurred to me.
Person1: Well, let's pray that's the only mistake you made.  Have you said anything to Barnes about this?
Person2: The timing has never seemed quite right.
Person1: Just keep your mouth shut, alright? This could mean everything to our careers, you know that?  Don't jeopardize this.
Person2: What -- are you threatening me?

Person1: What a weirdo that guy is!  Paranoid.  What's the matter with you?
Person2: Look I-I-I'll be okay.  I'll be okay.
Person1: It's not that big a deal.  We just didn't hit it off.
Person2: Now, look, you-you-you go on ahead.
Person1: Are you okay?  You look-- You're sweatin'. ELLIOT  Yeah.  Yeah, I just-just need so- some-some fresh air.  It's probably something I ate.  I'll-I'll walk. You go ahead.

Person1: What is your problem?  Why'd you snap at me?  I just wanted a statement.
Person2: I can't...I can't answer you just because you want me to answer you!
Person1: You didn't have to embarrass me in front of my colleagues.  You could give me something.
Person2: Oh, I'm sorry.  Did I embarrass you, sweetheart?  Oh...
Person1: Stop it.
Person2: Maybe I should just, ya know...turn to the cameras and say, do you mind if we just work something out?
Person1: Alright, alright, Eddie.  Don't patronize me.
Person2: I'm not.
Person1: Yes you are.  I'm not just some reporter.  I don't just stick a microphone in your face.  You could give me something.
Person2: Yeah, well you took the camera and put it right down on the evidence.  That was...
Person1: That was good.  You were holding the evidence.
Person2: You were merciless.  You didn't give a shit if you got me or not.
Person1: Well, who was it that taught me how to do that?  Huh?
Person2: You're ruthless.
Person1: You're not so bad yourself.

Person1: Shut you mouth or you'll be next.
Person2: You've stabbed me, man.
Person1: You were in my way.

Person1: Wait! I know how we can get in!
Person2: Jam, shut-up! You're not allowed to speak, remember? Go use whatever femmy idea you have to get yourself a ticket or four. I don't wanna hear it.
Person1: But... my plan involves all four of us acting together.
Person2: See you at 8

Person1: I want to go home.
Person2: But could I just tell you this one thing?
Person1: What?
Person2: This whole idea -- this date and everything. It was my parents' idea. They forced me into it.
Person1: Oh -- that's very nice of you to tell me.
Person2: No. What I mean is -- that's why I've been acting this way. I'm not like this. I hate myself like this.

Person1: The Good Witch...
Person2: Sailor... Lula loves you.
Person1: But I'm a robber and a manslaughterer and I haven't had any parental guidance.
Person2: She's forgiven you of all these things... You love her... Don't be afraid, Sailor.
Person1: But I'm wild at heart.
Person2: If you are truly wild at heart, you'll fight for your dreams... Don't turn away from love, Sailor... Don't turn away from love... Don't turn away from love.

Person1: Power cells.
Person2: They're coming.
Person1: Strange, not doin' a run-up on the main drive yet.  Strange unless he told you the particulars of my escape.
Person2: I got the quick-and-ugly version.
Person1: An' now you're worried about a repeat of history?
Person2: Entered our minds.
Person1: I asked what you thought.
Person2: You scare me, Riddick. That's what you wanna hear, isn't it? There, I admit it, Can I get back to work now?

Person1: What can I do for you?
Person2: Well, I was hoping you might stop by my office to swear out a criminal deposition against some of your friends and co-workers.
Person1: Is this a joke?
Person2: I don't believe it is, no.
Person1: Why the hell would I--
Person2: I've got photographs of you at the Trenton Ramada looking very--
Person1: That ain't me.
Person2: It's not?
Person1: You don't know who--
Person2: That's not you having a whiskey sour with Carmine Morada.
Person1: This is messed up. You don't know who's in that--
Person2: You're right, Mr. DePinto, and maybe I jumped the gun.
Person1: You're goddam right you jumped the gun.
Person2: That's probably not you in the picture. I tell you what, I'll just run the thing by the Grand Jury, see if they can't--
Person1: I want to talk to a goddam lawyer.
Person2: Good news there, Mr. DePinto, you're talking to one.

Person1: There's a tunnel out of the crypt into the barn. Did you know about that? There's an answer Mother. That's how she got out.
Person2: That's crazy. How could she find out about it?
Person1: Somebody told her.
Person2: Who?  That tun... that tunnel hasn't been used in fifty years.
Person1: Oh, would you stop lying Mother!
Person2: Why would I lie?
Person1: Because it's murder we're talking about. Aren't you concerned about what she told us about the other person in her room.
Person2: I'm concerned about her health.
Person1: Who was that person Mother?  Was it you?
Person2: If you believe this is murder, it is the Crown attorney you have to talk to, not me. And definitely not Agnes.

Person1: Did you forget to pay the electric bill? The lights were out when I came home.
Person2: No, I paid it last week. Maybe it's an issue with the provider.
Person1: We need to be more responsible with these things.
Person2: We already talked about this. I've been on top of our bills.
Person1: Okay, okay. I'm just worried. Let's call them tomorrow.

Person1: Courtney, you're going to have the peanut butter soup with smoked duck and mashed squash. New York magazine called it a 'playful but mysterious little dish." You'll love it. And then...the red snapper with violets and pine nuts. I think that'll follow nicely.
Person2: Mmmm...thanks, Patrick.

Person1: No, I didn't think she was. Let me get the picture here. Let me guess. She was an absolutely clean girl, a model daughter, she never had rebellious or impure thoughts, she didn't mess around...
Person2: If I was you, Mr. Mast, I'd watch my language.
Person1: Hey, I'm a private detective, Van Dorn, you want to hire a choir boy you can go back to Grand Rapids. I've been to that scumbag town. It's full of them.
Person2: Who's paying you?
Person1: You are.
Person2: That's right.
Person1: As I was saying, I'll pick up the thread. There's a number of ways I can go. There's not much you can do here. Stay if you want. Maybe it'd be better if you went back home. Go through Kristen's personal stuff. Ask around, maybe she knew somebody out here.  Look, I do this a lot. I work at a minimum rate of $750.00 a week. It may seem like a lot of money to you, but it ain't. You could hire cheaper.
Person2: And better?
Person1: I suppose. But I'll tell you, Jake, I'm like a little animal. When I get my teeth into something I never let go. If your daughter's here, I'll track her down.

Person1: Answer the question!
Person2: Do you know how long all this will last? Not thirty years... or thirty thousand years... but thirty thousand years... and you'll be part of it. Ages will roll... Ages. And you'll be here... the two of you... eternally frozen... frozen... beautiful.
Person1: There must be somebody else up here. I can't believe that he's --
Person2: Let me sculpt you and I will show you where the others have gone.
Person1: That's better.  How do you want us?
Person2: Nude. Imagine, a pair.
Person1: It'll be all right...

Person1: Juno MacGuff called while you were out running. She wants to know if you're coming to her little coffeehouse performance on Saturday.
Person2: Thanks for the message.
Person1: You know how I feel about her.
Person2: You've mentioned it about fifty times.
Person1: I just hope you don't consider her a close friend.

Person1: How would I get a loan, anyway?
Person2: You need collateral.
Person1: Like this?
Person2: That thing? Who'd you steal it from?
Person1: My daddy gave me this watch.
Person2: Yeah? Who'd he steal it from?
Person1: My daddy is dead so watch your mouth. You can say what you want about me, but don't be dragging my daddy into it. This watch means the world to me. Solid gold. Keeps perfect time.
Person2: Looks like a fake to me. Loan denied!

Person1: You're dying to come into my room, aren't you?
Person2: You want me so bad, why don't you invite me?

Person1: My name is Slovo, Czech secret police. When you are here you are under my jurisdiction, you take my orders, you do what I say. If you become any kind of an inconvenience, I'll shoot you.
Person2: Here we go again.
Person1: You're here because your government is putting pressure on my government. This is an internal affair, a Czech affair, that you are interfering with. I will warn you once. Don't shit in my lawn. Get whatever information your government seeks and get our.
Person2: First of all, you should kill whoever sold you that suit. Two, I don't wanna be here either, so just step off. Three, if you had the authority to shoot me you would've done it by now, so just ease up on the machismo, bitch. Now that we've got that sorted out, I'm gonna get some rest.

Person1: "Let all who love me follow me"... Where does God get mentioned?  Come on Jeanne, be honest.  You fought for yourself, in your name.
Person2: I... I was defending myself as best I could!  Everyone has the right to defend themselves, don't they?  Or should I have let myself be killed?
Person1: No, no, you did fine.  I'd even say well done.  Besides, most of the ones you killed probably deserved it, don't you think?
Person2: No, I do not think so.  I don't think that killing each other will ever bring peace.
Person1: I agree...

Person1: You're right. I remember Grandpierre looking through it. But there was nothing in it -- at least, nothing that the police thought was very important.
Person2: Can you remember anything at all?
Person1: Grandpierre asked me about an appointment Charles had -- on the day he was killed.
Person2: With whom? Where?
Person1: I think it only said where -- but I can't --
Person2: Think, Reggie, you've got to think -- it may be what we're looking for.
Person1: That money's not ours, Adam -- if we keep it, we'll be breaking the law.
Person2: Nonsense. We didn't steal it. There's no law against stealing stolen money.
Person1: Of course there is!
Person2: There is? Well, I can't say I think very much of a silly law like that. Think, Reggie -- please think -- what was written in Charles' notebook?
Person1: Well -- it was a place -- a street corner, I think. But I don't --  Hold it. I'm on.

Person1: We have to have a plan.
Person2: What sort of plan?
Person1: Our children cannot see us die first. If the Militia comes, you must hurry up to the roof. I will meet you there.
Person2: Please do not talk like this.
Person1: We have to. If I do not come, you must take them all by the hands and jump.

Person1: Steve...what you tried to do today...you tried to take me up on a high mountain...I couldn't go all the way...I failed you...  Will you forgive me?  Have I lost you, Steve?  Have I...?
Person2: Well, maybe I was wrong, too... But there's no doubt, Susie, that we have to face some serious things...
Person1: No one's ever stood up to my brother the way you did.
Person2: But you didn't do much about it, Susie.  You walked out, and there I was...solo...and not too good at that.
Person1: I just didn't think that I could antagonize him, Steve -- for OUR sake, I mean.
Person2: Susie, I was there for OUR sake, too.  But what a world it would be if we were all afraid to learn to walk and talk because it might offend poppa!  By the way, I think your brother was completely responsible for the smears...

Person1: Don't you remember you told me you loved me, baby...
Person2: Hey, I like this.

Person2: You don't have to do that.

Person2: I didn't. But it's a three-way tie between the Stooges, Patti Smith and the Runaways.
Person1: Yeah, I definitely need to make you some CDs. At least while my kid is hanging out in there.

Person2: We'll find him.

Person1: I never believed you were a murderer.  I knew.  I knew you are a magico.  I have seen it in you.  It's in your spirit.
Person2: I'm tired, Diego.  Go to bed.
Person1: You like to make the boundaries disappear.  It's not only the money, is it, George?  The adventure is part of the victory.  It's the thrill, ah?
Person2: Good night.
Person1: In my country, I am a magico.  A man with a dream.  A man on the rise.  To take nothing and make it something, okay?  I have failed my dream, but I will accomplish.  That is why I am in your country.  Yes, I lose my freedom. But they do not take my dream.  Do you have a dream, George?
Person2: I would if I could get some sleep.
Person1: Yes, you have a dream.  And maybe you accomplish your dream.  But yet you failed.  Why?
Person2: Because I got caught.
Person1: No, my brother.
Person2: Because they caught me?
Person1: You failed because you had the wrong dream.

Person1: Guess who? It's your old friend, Lex.
Person2: Luthor, I suspect if you had actually planted a bomb you'd be far away from here by now.
Person1: Silly me. How do I ever think I can fool the super guy. You're right, no bomb. I just knew you were too busy with the world peace bit to make a social call.  I confess . . . I tricked you. Hey, you look great!

Person1: ...Hello?
Person2: You're the nastiest dirtbag I know in this stinking City!
Person1: Hi Ma...
Person2: I've been playing twice a week for 20 years, 20 years I've been eating those shitty croquettes.

Person1: George, I am happy to see you.  How are you, my brother?
Person2: No more brothers, Diego.
Person1: Of course we are brothers.  Why do you say that?   You hurt me, George.
Person2: You betrayed me, Diego.
Person1: I did not.
Person2: You went behind my back and you cut me out.
Person1: No, I never.  I would not do that, George.  Never.

Person1: You're not looking at me, Harry.
Person2: Why do I have to keep looking at you?

Person2: You gonna get rough now, threaten me? I make good by tomorrow or get my legs broken?

Person2: Basketball game, damn it.

Person1: Sandro... A month is too long a time. I have become used to being without you.
Person2: You'll get over it soon. It's the usual anxiety.
Person1: A little more so this time.
Person2: So, it will just take you a little longer to get over it.
Person1: But I think we should talk about it. Or are you fully convinced that we too won't understand each other?
Person2: There will be plenty of time to talk about it later.  We'll  get married  soon.  That way we'll have more time...
Person1: In this case, getting married means nothing. Aren't we already the same as being married? And Corrado and Giulia -- aren't they already the same as being married?
Person2: But why rattle your brains by arguing and talking... Believe me, Anna, words never help at all. They only serve to confuse. I love you, Anna. Isn't I that enough?
Person1: No. It's not enough... I told you before that I would like to get away for a while and be alone.
Person2: But you just said that a month was too...
Person1: I mean, to stay away longer -- two months... a year... three years... Yes, I know, it sounds absurd. And I feel awful. The very idea of losing you makes me want to die... And yet... I... I just don't have the same feeling for you any more.
Person2: And what about yesterday... at my house... didn't you have any feeling for me, even then?
Person1: There you go... Must you always spoil everything!

Person1: Hey! Wait a minute! There's no birthday party for me here!
Person2: Thank you, Desmond.  What's the reason for your truancy?
Person1: I couldn't make it in time.
Person2: You mean, you couldn't? Or you wouldn't?
Person1: I don't know, mon. The food lines took forever.
Person2: Food will be eaten on your time!  Why are you continuously late for this class, Mr. Spicoli? Why do you shamelessly waste my time like this?
Person1: I don't know.

Person1: He was a town marshal... one night he surprised two burglars, coming out the back of a drugstore... They shot him.
Person2: Killed outright?
Person1: No. He was strong, he lasted almost a month. My mother - died when I was very young, so my father had become - the whole world to me... After he left me, I had nobody. I was ten years old.
Person2: You're very frank, Clarice. I think - it would be quite something to know you in private life.
Person1: Quid pro quo, Doctor.
Person2: The significance of the moth is change. Caterpillar into cocoon into beauty... Billy wants to change, too, Clarice. But there's the problem of his size, you see. Even if he were a woman, he'd have to be a big one...
Person1: Dr. Lecter, there's no correlation in the literature between transsexualism and violence. Transsexuals are very passive.
Person2: Clever girl. You're so close to the way you're going to catch him - do you realize that?
Person1: No. Tell me why.
Person2: After your father's death, you were orphaned. What happened next?  I don't imagine the answer's on those second-rate shoes, Clarice.
Person1: I went to live with my mother's cousin and her husband in Montana. They had a ranch.
Person2: A cattle ranch?
Person1: Horses - and sheep...
Person2: How long did you live there?
Person1: Two months.
Person2: Why so briefly?
Person1: I - ran away...
Person2: Why, Clarice? Did the rancher harm you?
Person1: No.
Person2: Did he try to?
Person1: No...! Quid pro quo, Doctor.
Person2: Billy's not a real transsexual, but he thinks he is. He tries to be. He's tried to be a lot of things, I expect.
Person1: You said - I was very close to the way we'd catch him.
Person2: There are three major centers for transsexual surgery: Johns Hopkins, the University of Minnesota, and Columbus Medical center. I wouldn't be surprised if Billy has applied for sex reassignment at one or all of them, and been rejected.
Person1: On what basis would they reject him?
Person2: The personality inventories would trip him up. Rorschach, Wechsler, House-Tree-Person... He wouldn't test like a real transsexual.
Person1: How would he test?

Person1: I wish you could see the world as I do. Deacon opened my eyes. There's no turning back from that.
Person2: I don't believe that.
Person1: You will. Time is on our side. Sooner or later, the Thirst always wins.

Person1: We think you should give up the magazine. Sell it. Let someone else run it. Whatever it takes.
Person2: We want you to go to college, find a career you love, marry a nice girl from a nice family, and live happily ever after.

Person1: I don't agree.  Why do you have to keep changing your mind all the time?

Person2: I never took pleasure in hurting anyone?

Person1: That's the general idea.  Only it's not so general as far as I'm concerned.

Person1: Only if I repeat them outside this room.  And, I will if I must...  Out there, for all to hear.  Or... you may speak, as planned.  But, you tell them you feel compelled to move on to greener pastures.

Person1: What needs sorting out?
