Person1: Yeah, well, I've stopped all that now.
Person2: We've noticed and we're glad.  But, you know... how are we going to make peace here?  We want to make things easier for you.  What can we do? Obviously I know how special Laura is, and I know things can't be good for you at the moment.  I'd hate it if I lost her.  But I'd like to think that if she decided she didn't want to see me anymore, I'd respect that decision.  Do you see what I'm saying?
Person1: Yeah.
Person2: Good.  So shall we leave it at that then?
Person1: I dunno.
Person2: Think about it, Rob.

Person1: We have to lose the window.
Person2: ...we can't lose the wind...
Person1: Then I can't do this shot...you wants me to push in--I can't push in through the window...We go back to New Hampshire?

Person1: Hey Gus--did you see the story idea I left on your desk?
Person2: Yeah--the blind foster home mother. It was good. I got Cahoon on it.
Person1: Oh. Cahoon. Yeah, he's--good.
Person2: Geller, we've been over this. You're a great copy editor. Maybe my best copy editor. You're not a reporter.

Person2: You know what separates us office flunkies from the reporters?
Person1: They don't have to be in the office Christmas show?
Person2: A flack jacket.
Person1: A--flack jacket.
Person2: Every Tom, Dick, and Harry thinks he can write. But a journalist gets in there, right where the bombs are. He's aggressive. Grabs the bull by the balls.
Person1: You don't think I can grab bulls' balls?
Person2: Geller, you don't want a reporter's life. They're very--messy. You're all about order. Control. And getting me my copy by five.

Person2: That is a problem. There is no description of Juntao. No known photograph.

Person1: Wrap her up in blankets. Bring the car around to the back of the hotel, throw her off the balcony, put her in the car...Done.
Person2: You don't think someone will have a problem with a body being thrown off a balcony?
Person1: We check out the area and wait for a time when it's clear.
Person2: What about the blood?
Person1: Someone goes to Walmart, gets some buckets, brushes, mops, Spic and Span, the works.
Person2: Have you ever done this before?
Person1: The reality is, you take away the horror of this situation, take away the tragedy of the death, take away the moral and ethical implications of all the crap you have had conditioned, beaten, into your head since grade one. What are we left with? What? A 115 lb. problem. 115 lbs. that must be moved from point A to point B. Now, a straight line in the shortest distance but we are denied the luxury of a visible straight line. But that line exists and I see it.I see that line. Trust me. Adam. Trust me...I can take care of this.

Person1: Listen to me, Neo.  I know why you're afraid to go through that door.  You can't get free of thinking that I could be wrong.  You must believe me.  There is a greatness inside of you, Neo.  A greatness that is going to lift you to unimaginable heights and that in time will change the world.
Person2: Morpheus, I don't know --
Person1: I know.  That is why it is so important for you to go.  Please, Neo, I'm asking you to find whatever respect you may have for me and trust me.

Person1: Gillian... Would the whales be at sea by now?
Person2: Yes... If you have a chart on board, I can show you.
Person1: All I need is the radio frequency to track them.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm coming with you.
Person1: You can't. Our next stop is the 23rd Century.
Person2: What do I care? I've got nobody but those whales...
Person1: I have no time to argue, Gillian. Or even tell you how much you've meant to us... The frequency.
Person2: All right. The frequency is 401 megahertz.
Person1: Thank you. For everything.  Beam me up, Scotty.

Person1: Sugar and cream for Goetz; I take mine black.  You're absolutely correct.  The politicians don't want panic headlines spoiling the Festival of Love.
Person2: Well, let's thank God you and Inspector Goetz are on the case, then.
Person1: Would you want to work with us on this?
Person2: Oh, my God, no!  I'm a clinical hysteric, with panic syndrome, and anxiety neurosis, agoraphobic, I'm afraid of everything, real and imaginary.  I never leave this apartment now.  Nobody ever comes here.  I just wanted to get your attention.  I write and I used to lecture on these crimes, but... I'm not competent.
Person1: I think you are.  I really admire everything you've done; it would be an honor to work with you, and we need all the help we can get, especially yours.
Person2: Inspector Halloran, that is so much bullshit, you don't like or admire me, but the beautiful part is I don't give a care.  That's the upside of having a breakdown.
Person1: Well, it's a hell of an apartment you got here.  I'm living one step away from the projects, myself, but I get to go to work every day, wading in blood and guts.  I guess the books you wrote about these sons of bitches paid off pretty good.
Person2: Will you go.  Andy, make them go.
Person1: You can't go out lecturing?  Tough shit.  Women are dying.  Where can I lay this stuff out?

Person1: Look, I can understand if you and Foley are close.

You can help him and risk going down again, get cuffed and shackled, hope to God you pull a reasonable judge, not some hard-on.  Or, if you want to play it another way...

Person1: Now look -- please --
Person2: Ben, I think we're two civilized human beings. Do you think it's necessary to threaten each other?

Person2: Do you want to unclench your fists, please? Thank you. I can see in the dark, you know. I've been here quite a while.

Person1: No, I don't.
Person2: Well, I don't think we have a whole lot to say to each other, Ben. I do think you should know the consequences of what you've done. I do think you should know that my wife and I are getting a divorce soon.

Person2: Why?
Person1: It shouldn't make any difference what happened.
Person2: That's quite a statement.

Person2: Shaking hands. Well, that's not saying much for my wife, is it?

In the light of what's happened I think maybe I can get you behind bars if you ever look at my daughter again. I have seen Elaine and I have spent the afternoon taking steps to insure...

Young trophy wife, I mean, in the parlance of our times, owes money all over town, including to known pornographers-- and that's cool, that's cool-- but I'm saying, she needs money, and of course they're gonna say they didn't get it 'cause she wants more, man, she's gotta feed the monkey, I mean-- hasn't that ever occurred to you...? Sir?

You think they want "suspected communists" entertaining the American public with party propaganda like, gosh I don't know, "Sand Pirates of the Sahara?"

Person1: I know how you feel, Miss Kubelik. You think it's the end of the world -- but it's not, really. I went through exactly the same thing myself.
Person2: You did?
Person1: Well, maybe not exactly -- I tried to do it with a gun.
Person2: Over a girl?
Person1: Worse than that -- she was the wife of my best friend -- and I was mad for her. But I knew it was hopeless -- so I decided to end it all. I went to a pawnshop and bought a forty-five automatic and drove up to Eden Park -- do you know Cincinnati?
Person2: No, I don't.
Person1: Anyway, I parked the car and loaded the gun -- well, you read in the papers all the time that people shoot themselves, but believe me, it's not that easy -- I mean, how do you do it? -- here, or here, or here --  -- you know where I finally shot myself?
Person2: Where?
Person1: Here.
Person2: In the knee?
Person1: Uh-huh. While I was sitting there, trying to make my mind up, a cop stuck his head in the car, because I was illegally parked -- so I started to hide the gun under the seat and it went off -- pow!
Person2: That's terrible.
Person1: Yeah. Took me a year before I could bend my knee -- but I got over the girl in three weeks. She still lives in Cincinnati, has four kids, gained twenty pounds -- she sends me a fruit cake every Christmas.
Person2: Are you just making that up to make me feel better?
Person1: Of course not. Here's the fruit cake.  And you want to see my knee?

Person1: Why not?

I see that they're nothing, I see they ain't here. The only thing that's here is you. And me. I want you to come upstairs. Now. I tried to take everything last night, like you told me, but I couldn't. I couldn't take everything in a hundred years. It's the way we are. We compound each other.
Person1: Let me go home.
Person2: No.
Person1: Let me go home.
Person2: No.
Person1: I'm freezing to death.
Person2: Come upstairs. I don't care why you come. No, that's not what I mean. Loretta, I love you. Not like they told you love is and I didn't know this either. But love don't make things nice, it ruins everything, it breaks your heart, it makes things a mess. We're not here to make things perfect. Snowflakes are perfect. The stars are perfect. Not us. We are here to ruin ourselves and break our hearts and love the wrong people and die! The storybooks are bullshit. Come upstairs with me, baby! Don't try to live your life out to somebody else's idea of sweet happiness. Don't try to live on milk and cookies when what you want is meat! Red meat just like me! It's wolves run with wolves and nothing else! You're a wolf just like me! Come upstairs with me and get in my bed! Come on! Come on! Come on!

Person1: Now listen to what I've got to say. I took up this profession when I was ten years old. In those days there weren't these modern machines. The films were silent. The projectors were run by hand, like this, with a crank. And you wound the crank all day long. It was really rough going! If you got tired and slowed down' boom! Everything would go up in flames!
Person2: Then why don't you want to teach it to me too? Now that there's no more cranking, and it's easier?
Person1: Because I don't want to, Toto! This is not a job for you. It's like being a slave. You're always alone. You see the same film over and over again, because you have nothing else to do. And you start talking to Greta Garbo and Tyrone Power like a nut! You work on holidays, on Christmas, on Easter. Only on Good Friday are you free. But if they hadn't put Jesus Christ on a cross...You'd work Good Fridays too!
Person2: Then why don't you change jobs?
Person1: Because I'm an idiot. How many other guys in town know how to be a projectionist? None! Only a jerk like me could do it. Besides I wasn't lucky. When I was a kid there was the war! When I grew up, another war! Now it's all different. Times have changed. And you want to be a dope like me? Huh? Answer me!
Person2: No...
Person1: Good for you, Toto. Good for you... I'm only saying this for your own good...  Cooped up in here you die of heat in the summer and of cold in the winter. You breathe in smoke, gas fumes, and earn practically nothing.
Person2: But don't you like anything about what you do?
Person1: With time...you get used to it. Besides, when you hear from up here that there's a full house and that people are laughing, having fun... Then you're happy too.  So I've been wasting my breath? You pretend to agree with me, but as soon as my back is turned, you do what you want!  Get out of here! I don't want to lay eyes on you again! This is the last straw! Your mother's right, you're crazy!!  But how'd he do it? The little bastard! By watching, he's learned! It's incredible!  I'm letting the box office know you're not to set foot even into the theatre! There are no more tickets for you! And I'm also talking to Father Adelfio! You won't be an altar boy any more either!!! You little runt!
Person2: Alfredo, go forget yourself!

Person1: Me, I'm riding along, minding my own business. Four cowboys come by and we decide to ride together for a while, friendly as can be. I always figure you might as well approach life like everybody's your friend or nobody is... don't make much difference. We get out in the middle of that frying pan and suddenly everybody's pointing their gun but me. I guess they admired my horse. She's a great one, a sweet little bay.
Person2: Looks like that's not all they admired.
Person1: Yup. The whole rig. I don't care much about the rest, but I surely will miss that bay. Least they didn't kill me. That was right considerate, I thought. They were laughing when they left me. Thought it was real funny. I walked for a little while but there was no use, so I gave it up. Figured it was just bad luck.

Same way Grace played us this morning.  I don't like that, Jake.  Not twice in one day.  And maybe I'm so pissed I'd twist the next off my own Grandma to get out of here.

Give me two- hundred.  I'll kill her and dump the body where no one will ever find it. But I need the money.  I've got to have the money.

Person1: Come on, Fran -- don't be like that. You just going to sit there and keep bawling?  You won't talk to me, you won't tell me what's wrong --  Look, I know you think I'm stalling you. But when you've been married to a woman for twelve years, you don't just sit down at the breakfast table and say "Pass the sugar -- and I want a divorce." It's not that easy.  Anyway, this is the wrong time. The kids are home from school -- my in- laws are visiting for the holidays -- I can't bring it up now.  This isn't like you, Fran -- you were always such a good sport -- such fun to be with --
Person2: Yeah -- that's me. The Happy Idiot -- a million laughs.
Person1: Well, that's more like it. At least you're speaking to me.
Person2: Funny thing happened to me at the office party today -- I ran into your secretary -- Miss Olsen. You know -- ring-a-ding-ding? I laughed so much I like to died.
Person1: Is that what's been bothering you -- Miss Olsen? That's ancient history.
Person2: I was never very good at history. Let me see -- there was Miss Olsen, and then there was Miss Rossi -- no, she came before -- it was Miss Koch who came after Miss Olsen --
Person1: Now, Fran --
Person2: And just think -- right now there's some lucky girl in the building who's going to come after me --
Person1: Okay, okay, Fran. I deserve that. But just ask yourself -- why does a man run around with a lot of girls? Because he's unhappy at home -- because he's lonely, that's why -- all that was before you, Fran -- I've stopped running.

Person1: Peter, if you want me to run your little camping trip, there are two conditions.  First -- I'm in charge, and when I'm not around, Dieter is.  Your job is to sign the checks, tell us we're doing a good job, and open your case of scotch when we have a good day.  Second condition -- my fee.  You can keep it.  All I want in exchange for my services is the right to hunt one of the tyrannosaurs.  A male.  Buck only.  Why and how are my business. If you don't  like either of those conditions, you're on your own.  Go ahead and set up your camp right here, or in a swamp, or in the middle of a rex nest, for all I care.  But I've been on too many safaris with rich dentists to listen to any more suicidal ideas.  Okay?
Person2: Okay.
Person1: Good lad.

Person2: Yes, but... I thought...

Person1: Finish your tour?

Person1: Yes- but their suffering is only transitory- once they except God into their hearts, He will vanquish all pain.

Person1: You see, Wilhelm, I'm talking about ordinary, everyday reasons. Which is why I want to discuss your private life.  How many illegitimate children do you have?
Person2: Major, I don't see how this line of questioning could...
Person1: David, what are you Counsel for the Defence now?  Did you hear the question?

Person1: Whoever tossed this place wants you.  And I'm looking to stay outta the line of fire.
Person2: How's this about me?
Person1: They lifted my wallet to make it look like a robbery.  But there's a bug in my computer keyboard, a tap on the phone and a mike in the light fixture.
Person2: Like you said, maybe somebody's tracking one of your investigations.
Person1: Hardware's too sophisticated.  It's gotta be the government.  And why do I think they're looking for you?
Person2: You're crazy.
Person1: I'm you, I take that money and get outta town while you can.

Person1: So you've not lit the last four boilers then?
Person2: No, but we're making excellent time.
Person1: Captain, the press knows the size of Titanic, let them marvel at her speed too. We must give them something new to print. And the maiden voyage of Titanic must make headlines!
Person2: I prefer not to push the engines until they've been properly run in.
Person1: Of course I leave it to your good offices to decide what's best, but what a glorious end to your last crossing if we get into New York Tuesday night and surprise them all.  Retire with a bang, eh, E.J.?

Person1: Just imagine somebody like your quasi-fat, goody-good friend Betty Finn doing a Crest commercial. No one would buy Crest.
Person2: Don't tell me. Crest would be stained with loserness.
Person1: Yeah, and who wants that on their teeth?

Person1: Easy, hon, I was just looking for fun details --
Person2: Oh, well, why didn't you say so? And oh, I don't know if you're interested in this detail, but I was just about to tell you that I love him.  I love him, and I don't care what you think.  I love him for the guy he wants to be, and I love him for the guy he almost is. I love him.

Person1: ...Paulie, why didn't you tell me you were bringing him home?! Look at me, I'm not ready for this.
Person2: Like it would make a difference if you were, right? This guy's a friend and now he's takin' ya out.
Person1: No... I can't!
Person2: Ya, ya goin' outta the bedroom an' I don't wanna know from nothin'.
Person1: Paulie, please --
Person2: Hey, I want ya out instamaticly. -- I'm sicka lookin' at ya hangin' around like a friggin' spider -- Go out -- Live! Do, enjoy life.
Person1: ...Like you?
Person2: Don't get wise with me. I want ya to stop bein' a loser.
Person1: I can't go out.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Paulie, it's Thanksgiving. I've gotta turkey in the oven.

Person1: ...the lease, the phones, the cars...layers of false ident. Would take the FBI weeks.  How long did it take them?  Three hours? Four?  This means, "We can reach out and touch somebody."  Like Bad Teleflora.
Person2: ...even if they could run the identities you built to EPIC, all they'll find is more cover... Trust what you built.  It's quality, girl.  We're cool...
Person1: ...you are trying to reassure me because you know when people get anxious, they make mistakes. You're worried about me.  Do not be.  I am careful.  I am cool.  I got Trudy, backup, whatever.  You worry about you.  Because you are the ones who are in denied territory, not me.  If your focus is on me, you'll miss something coming at you.  That's how people slip up. Get hurt.  And I'd die if anything happened.  You worry about you. You and Sonny...are in the dangerous place.  I'm fine...

Person2: Well, then?

Person2: Take another look at these two.

Person1: He couldn't look at me.  But I looked at him.  Right at him.  His secret was mine now.  We used to share it.  But not anymore.  Now, I owned it completely.
Person2: Well, okay.  I'll take you about nine-thirty in the morning.  That's okay with you?
Person1: Great.

Person2: Really?  What was it like?  A down payment now, then a bonus for sleeping with me?
Person1: I didn't care about the money.
